reviewText: The premise for this movie is pure Warner Bros at its less than wonderful. An irresponsible star finds himself beholding to a mobster and a cute hoofer tries to help him. Filmed near the end of the Joelson/Keeler union, this film like the marriage sank fast and for the most part has slipped into mediocre film oblivion. The script is less than inspired, Keeler's dancing isn't quite as snappy, and this would undoubtedly be forgotten if not for the hammy and utterly energetic musical numbers delivered by Jolson with his usual bravado.Al Dubin and Harry Warren whipped up A Quarter To Nine which became one of Jolson's later signature songs. Additionally, this movie also features one of my favorites Latin From Manhattan. For me, this number makes this clunker worthwhile. The lyrics are funny and Jolson really milks this one for all it's worth.The egomaniacal and cocky Jolson dominates this film while his soon to be ex fades in the background. They don't make films like this anymore, but I miss the musical numbers which go over the top.As for this print, no remastering here. It is one of those DVDs on request from the Warner Archive. Still, I am glad they realized there is a demand for Jolson 62 years after his death.3* for the stupid premise but 5* for the music and Jolson.

reviewText: The Warners Archive Collection are releasing many films which may otherwise not be available on DVD.  Sadly, the prints are unrestored, the DVDs very expensive and there are no extras beyond theatrical trailers. "Go into Your Dance" is a case in point. Released in 1935, the film is the only teaming of husband and wife Al Jolson and Ruby Keeler. Warners threw the lot into this one - gangsters, musical numbers, comedy - because the teaming of Jolson and Keeler was big news.Based on a story by Bradford Ropes, who wrote the story on which "42nd Street" was based, the film has some great Dubin and Warren hits such as "About a Quarter to Nine" and "She's a Latin from Manhattan", all presented with that distinctive Warner Brother's sound directed by Leo Forbstein and arranged by Ray Heindhorf. There is a good supporting cast including witty Glenda Farrell and Patsy Kelly. Jolson plays an egomaniac performer (like himself) and Keeler plays his sidekick and eventual romantic partner (like herself). Keeler, in particular, has a much more expansive acting role than usual and does very well. The musical numbers are a little odd, mixing his robust singing with her more modest hoofing. Also, she does some Spanish dancing and certainly looks like a Latin from Manhattan! One of the highlights of the film is the appearance with one song of the great Helen Morgan, atop a piano just as she did in New York nightclubs. She sings straight to the camera and is sensational.This potpourri would be just fine, whether as an historical record of the leads and Morgan or simply as an entertaining and very typical Warner Brother's product but the print is poor and the film suffers accordingly. The original trailer is included.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Warner Bros. musicals of the 1930's are very dated, but are very enjoyable when they contain the elaborate Busby Berkeley musical numbers. In his day, Jolson may have been a show-stopper at the Winter Garden, but not in the movies. Unfortunately I don't know of anyone old enough to have seen him in person, but on the screen he plays Jolson at the Winter Garden with bad scripts. The musical numbers are laughable and make no sense. The only bright spot in the film was Patsy Kelly and some of Ruby Keeler's tap dancing in the beginning of the film. Otherwise, an overall misfire.
Title: N/A

reviewText: More plot than music, only 2 good songs (that's 2 more than Wonder Bar had by the same team), picture and sound (the other two reviews notwithstanding) were just fine, it was not overpriced in the least unless its age is considered (older movies are usually cheaper), the production numbers were of course ridiculous (cast of hundreds and 5 different sets on the stage of a night club), the plot (simplistic at first) got believable and suspenseful, I'd like to have seen Keeler dance to the title tune, but was happy to see Jolson do it. Patsy Kelly made more of an impression on me than Helen Morgan did, and Morgan's single song was just - bad.  Overall I'm very glad I bought/watched it and would recommend it to anyone who likes this kind of flick.  And Jolson's character was an irresponsible super star, not an "egomaniac".
Title: N/A

reviewText: Although it lags at time, although it is trite at times you gotta get Go Into Your Dance. The film shows it's age but it is quite watchable and the quality of the video and sound is pretty good. Keeler's Chicago nightclub turn is quite enchanting. The sequence with Jolson at the piano putting Keeler through her dance paces is priceless. A Quarter to Nine is infectious although the musical sequence sort of misfires with inexplicable slices of Jolson and performers going back and forth into blackface for no other reason than to remind us that this is Jolson. Really enjoyed the drama sequence where Jolson's life is threatened and Keeler saves him and Jolson coming to the aid of his jailed sister. Loved the brief number Go Into Your Dance with Jolson in blackface wringing pathos from the tune and showing how appealing he could be. Last but not least- the part of Latin from Manhattan with Keeler and Jolson standing on top of the world in a glimpse of Busby Berkeley at his most imaginative. Hints of the future 42nd Street pop up as well. I waited till Amazon had it at $10.99,but the price seems to vary day to day. As a Jolson fan and someone who fell in love with Keeler in 42nd Street I had a blast.
summary: Buy it for Keeler,buy it for Jolson,buy it for A Latin From Manhattan....
Title: N/A

reviewText: That's how Al Jolson, in his prime, was billed, and for my money he was just that. (It was said that Jolson sang every song as if it was the last song he would ever sing.) And I found the print quality surprisingly good for a 1935 film.Helen Morgan is always worth seeing. Today she's in danger of being forgotten. (Never mind the silly biopic with the miscast Ann Blyth, and catch the great 1936 film of "Show Boat" -- Morgan sings "Bill," and Paul Robeson performs "Old Man River" -- two immortal moments in film musicals.)I thought there were a good half dozen numbers that were well worth seeing. All told, this is a golden oldie that I'm glad I bought.
summary: The greatest entertainer in the world.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Jolson could always elevate a weak script, even with occasional mincing, awkward acting (talking about *movies*, not stage), but here he has solid support, and two terrific numbers, "About A Quarter To Nine", a beat ballad, given the full 1935 Hollywood production treatment, Jolson and real-life wife (star on her own) Ruby Keeler, ascending the stairs and the stars to a huge time-piece, to which Ruby offers a clever juxtaposition (it's corny but will bring a smile); and "She's A Latin From manhattan" - in which they both seem to enjoy this number, Ruby moving sensuously in a satiny gown. Of course, we have to have a "Mammy song", and we get a good one, "Mammy, I'll Sing About You" (done live on CD by none other than Tiny Tim as "Mother, I'll Sing About You"). Jolson's theatrics are sensational and the Director and Editor let him shine.Jolson stopped recording in 1932 and one imagines that "A Quarter To Nine" and "She's A Latin From Manhattan" might have proven to be two more million-sellers for AJ. (He returned to recording in 1945).For those who want to know every detail of Al's career *and* homelife, this picture holds some ironic interest. I believe that the couple parted sometime after this musical - but their scenes together reveal nothing of despair or frustration. In fact, the climactic scene backstage where Ruby, bedridden, urges him to take the stage and not worry about her, is one of the very best (outside genre) this Reviewer has ever witnessed.Another remarkable aspect is in Jolson's acting - he's not consistently excellent - but compared to earlier cinematic efforts, he's positively Oscar-worthy!It was mentioned above that this musical was made a few years after Jolson stopped visistying recording studios and the film itself really pointed the way to another sudden, long-stretch, for the artist: he'd do *one* more starring vehicle, the following year, THE SINGING KID, where he actually parodies his own image!I wonder if some AJ fans do not realize that when THE JOLSON STORY was released in 1946, there was a full decade of "semi-retirement", when he struggled to stay afloat in the radio business.Helen Morgan and Patsy Kelley have excellents scenes in this 1935 minor classic, Helen, as the Diva with evil designs on Al; Patsy, a loopy, amateurish "hoofer" who drives Jolson crazy until she brings him a needed smile at one crucial point in the plot.Passable print. Lighting is low; some footage is scratchy. Volume down.Some racial stereotyping.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Go Into your Dance is mostly a good movie. Al Jolson sings wonderfully, his wife (this is the only movie they did together) Ruby Keeler was a fair dancer and there is some very good banter. The plot is drawn from the same book that would later give us 42 Street. An unlikely bonus is the presence of some strong female characters, perhaps more visible because every male character except Al Jolson is backdrop.Jolson, as Al Howard plays an irresponsible Broadway star with a habit of skipping on performances, leaving the cast and theater owner stuck. He is on a rather humorous bender in Mexico long enough to find out that he has been banned from every stage back in New York , to sing a few numbers and to cut up with several minor characters. His sister arrives, played by Glenda Ferrell who gets him a gig in a Detroit night club having promised the nightclub owner that Al's new partner would keep him on the job. The problem being to get the partner, enter Ruby Keeler, as "Dot" Wayne.From here we have some fairly conventional shots of song and dance rehearsals. The choreography credit is listed as Bobby Connolly (dances created and staged by) however they have the look of pre Busby Berkeley or maybe Busby Berkeley without the money for crane shots. Mixed in is something like a romantic subplot along with gangsters and the then common black face singing and a black actor in a comedic menial role.By adding in the sub plot involving the gangers we are set up for Ms. Keeler's dramatic close ups and one of the single worst performances of a dramatic line ever to ever escape the blooper reel. I say this risking a spoiler, but a line this bad and badly delivered is worth respect and sitting to the end to make sure you heard it right.As an Al Jolson fan, I am glad I have this movie. His singing alone is worth the cost. His delivery of comic lines are generally fun moments, and it was interesting to realize how stiff he appears when singing or avoiding the dance numbers. Most of the female supporting roles have fun and decent lines. There is even a cameo appearance by British actor Arthur Treacher. His role is like the other male leads is cardboard, but he does help set up a gag for Glenda Ferrell.Altogether this is a nice popcorn movie. Fans of Al Jolson, Ruby Keeler or the musical should enjoy this early movie musical. Other may prefer it as a one-time rental or instant view.  I will be replaying my DVD.
summary: Fun repartee the great voice of Al Jolson and one of the worst dramatic deliveries in all of film history
Title: N/A
